translated: Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

As for the relationship between these twelve sense bases and the six wholesome sense bases, the six wholesome sense bases subsume a small portion of four sense bases, and a small portion of four sense bases also subsumes the six wholesome sense bases.

As for the relationship with the five unwholesome sense bases, the five unwholesome sense bases subsume a small portion of four sense bases, and a small portion of four sense bases also subsumes the five unwholesome sense bases.

As for the relationship with the seven indeterminate sense bases, the seven indeterminate sense bases subsume eight sense bases and a small portion of four sense bases, and eight sense bases and a small portion of four sense bases also subsume the seven indeterminate sense bases.

As for the relationship with the three sense bases with outflows, the three sense bases with outflows subsume a small portion of one sense base, and a small portion of one sense base also subsumes the three sense bases with outflows.

As for the relationship with the five sense bases with outflows, the five sense bases with outflows subsume ten sense bases and a small portion of two sense bases, and ten sense bases and a small portion of two sense bases also subsume the five sense bases with outflows.
As for the relationship with the eight pure sense bases, the eight pure sense bases subsume part of two sense bases, and part of two sense bases also subsumes the eight pure sense bases.

As for how many are past, etc., eleven are either past, future, or present, and one should be distinguished, namely, the sense base of mental objects. If conditioned, it is either past, future, or present; if unconditioned, it is neither past, future, nor present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., eight are indeterminate, and four should be distinguished.
Namely, the sense base of form is either wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to wholesome bodily expression.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to unwholesome bodily expression.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to all sense bases of form other than wholesome and unwholesome bodily expression.
The sense base of sound is either wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to wholesome verbal expression.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to unwholesome verbal expression.
What is neutral?
It refers to the sound element other than the bodily and verbal manifest actions of good and bad.
The mind element may be good, bad, or neutral.
What is good?
It refers to the mind element associated with good attention.
What is bad?
It refers to the mind element associated with bad attention.
What is neutral?
It refers to the mind element associated with neutral attention.
The dharma element may be good, bad, or neutral.
What is good?
It refers to the good bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma element, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation, as well as cessation through contemplation.
What is bad?
It refers to the bad bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma element, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation.
What is neutral?
It refers to the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation, as well as space and cessation not through contemplation.
As for how many are bound to the desire realm and so forth, two are bound to the desire realm, and ten should be distinguished.
It is the eye base, which may be connected to the desire realm or the form realm.
How is it connected to the desire realm?
It is the eye base that is derived from the great elements of the desire realm.
How is it connected to the form realm?
It is the eye base that is derived from the great elements of the form realm.
The form, ear, sound, nose, tongue, and body bases are also like this.
The tangible base may be connected to the desire realm or the form realm.
How is it connected to the desire realm?
It is the tangible base that is the four great elements of the desire realm and that which is derived from the great elements of the desire realm.
How is it connected to the form realm?
It is the tangible base that is the four great elements of the form realm and that which is derived from the great elements of the form realm.
The mind base may be connected to the desire realm, the form realm, the formless realm, or it may be unconditioned.
How is it connected to the desire realm?
It is the mind base associated with the attention of the desire realm.
How is it connected to the form realm?
It is the mind base associated with the attention of the form realm.
How is it connected to the formless realm?
It refers to the mind base associated with the volition of the formless realm.
What is unconditioned?
It refers to the mind base associated with the volition of the uncontaminated [realm].
The dharma realm may be bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, bound to the formless realm, or unconditioned.
What is bound to the desire realm?
It refers to the desire realm's bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma realm, as well as the aggregate of feeling, perception, and mental formations of the desire realm.
What is bound to the form realm?
It refers to the form realm's bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma realm, as well as the aggregate of feeling, perception, and mental formations of the form realm.
What is bound to the formless realm?
It refers to the aggregate of feeling, perception, and mental formations of the formless realm.
What is unconditioned?

It refers to the uncontaminated bodily and verbal actions, as well as the aggregate of feeling, perception, and mental formations of the uncontaminated [realm], along with the three unconditioned [dharmas].
As for how many are learner [dharmas], etc., ten are neither learner nor post-learner [dharmas], and two should be distinguished.
It means the mind base may be a learner [dharma], a post-learner [dharma], or neither a learner nor post-learner [dharma].
What is a learner [dharma]?
It refers to the mind base associated with the volition of a learner.
What is non-learner?
It is the mind base associated with the attention of a non-learner.
What is neither learner nor non-learner?
It is the mind base associated with defiled attention.
The dharma base may be learner, non-learner, or neither learner nor non-learner.
What is learner?
It is the bodily and verbal actions of a learner, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation of a learner.
What is non-learner?
It is the bodily and verbal actions of a non-learner, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation of a non-learner.
What is neither learner nor non-learner?
It is the defiled bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma base, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation of a defiled nature, and space and the two cessations.
As for these twelve bases, how many are to be eliminated by seeing, and so on? Ten are to be eliminated by cultivation, and two should be distinguished.
That is to say, the mind base may be eliminated by seeing, by cultivation, or not to be eliminated.
What is eliminated by seeing?

It is the mind base eliminated by the perseverance for the realization of the fruit of the stream-enterer stage of the path of seeing in the case of the faith-to-ideals and doctrines-to-ideals faculties.
What is this again?
It refers to the mind base associated with the eighty-eight latent afflictions that are to be eliminated by the path of seeing.
What is eliminated by cultivation?
It refers to the mind base that is eliminated by the path of cultivation of the learners who have entered the stream.
What is this?
It refers to the mind base associated with the ten latent afflictions that are eliminated by the path of cultivation, as well as the defiled and impure mind base.
What is not to be eliminated?
It refers to the pure mind base.
The dharma base may be eliminated by the path of seeing, by the path of cultivation, or not to be eliminated.
What is eliminated by the path of seeing?
It refers to the dharma base eliminated by the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing of the followers of faith and followers of the teaching.
What is this?

It refers to the eighty-eight latent afflictions that are eliminated by the path of seeing, as well as the dharma base associated with them and the formations dissociated from the mind that arise together with them.
What is eliminated by the path of cultivation?
It refers to the dharma base eliminated by the path of cultivation of the learners who have entered the stream.
What is this?

It is the ten contaminants that are to be eliminated by cultivation, as well as the factors of the realm that are associated with them, and the bodily and verbal actions that are unmanifested and arise from them, and the formations that are not associated with mind, and the defiled factors of the realm.
What is not to be eliminated?

It is the pure factors of the realm.ğŸ”½As for how many are not mind, etc., ten are neither mind nor mental factors nor associated with mind, one is only mind, and one should be distinguished, namely the factor realm. If it has an object, it is a mental factor and associated with mind; if it has no object, it is neither mind nor mental factors nor associated with mind.

As for how many are concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling, etc., ten are neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling, one is associated with feeling but not concomitant with mind, and one should be distinguished, namely the factor realm. It may be concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling, or it may be both concomitant with mind and associated with feeling, or it may be neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling.

That which is concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling refers to the bodily and verbal actions and formations not directly associated with mind that are concomitant with mind, as well as feeling.
That which is both concomitant with mind and associated with feeling refers to the aggregate of perception and the aggregate of formations associated with mind.

That which is neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling refers to the bodily and verbal actions and formations not directly associated with mind that are not concomitant with mind, as well as the unconditioned dharmas.
As for how many are concomitant with mind but not associated with the aggregate of volitional formations, except for its own nature, it should be understood like feeling.

As for how many are concomitant with investigation but not associated with deliberation, ten are neither concomitant with investigation nor associated with deliberation, and two should be distinguished.
Namely, the sense base of mind may be with investigation and deliberation, or without investigation but only with deliberation, or without investigation or deliberation.
What is with investigation and deliberation?
It refers to the sense base of mind associated with attention with investigation and deliberation.
What is without investigation but only with deliberation?
It refers to the sense base of mind associated with attention without investigation but only with deliberation.
What is without applied thought and sustained thought?
It is the mental faculty associated with the attention that is without applied thought and sustained thought.
The element of mental objects has four cases.

Either it is associated with applied thought and does not occur with sustained thought, referring to the bodily and verbal actions and formations dissociated from the mind that occur with applied thought, and the sustained thought that is associated with applied thought.
Or it is associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought, referring to the mental factors that are associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought.
Or it is associated with both applied thought and sustained thought, referring to the mental factors that are associated with both applied thought and sustained thought.

Or it is neither associated with applied thought nor with sustained thought, referring to the bodily and verbal actions and formations dissociated from the mind that are not associated with applied thought, the sustained thought that is not associated with applied thought, and the mental factors and unconditioned dharmas that are without applied thought and sustained thought.
As for how many are views and yet are not objects of views, etc., one is both a view and an object of views, nine are objects of views but not views, and two should be distinguished.
It is the mental faculty. If it is contaminated, it is a basis of views but not views. If it is uncontaminated, it is neither a basis of views nor views.
The element of factors has four alternatives.
Either it is views and not a basis of views, namely uncontaminated discernment not included in the knowledge of elimination and non-production.
Or it is a basis of views but not views, namely the element of factors that is contaminated and not included in views.
Or it is both views and a basis of views, namely the five defiled views and conventional right views.
Or it is neither views nor a basis of views, namely the element of factors that is uncontaminated and not included in views.
As for how many are causes of the view of self but not the view of self as a cause, eight are not causes of the view of self but not the view of self as a cause, four should be distinguished.

Namely, the form element. If it is defiled, it is a cause of the view of self but not the view of self as a cause. If it is undefiled, it is neither a cause of the view of self nor the view of self as a cause.
The sound element is also like this.

analyzed: æ„è™•ï¼Œæˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› äº¦æœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–éæœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€‚
translated: The mind base is either a cause of the view of self but not a cause of the view of self, or it is a cause of the view of self and also a cause of the view of self, or it is neither a cause of the view of self nor a cause of the view of self.

The mind base that is a cause of the view of self but not a cause of the view of self refers to the defiled mind base other than the mind base associated with the past and present fetters eliminated by the path of seeing suffering, also other than the mind base associated with the past and present pervasive fetters eliminated by the path of seeing the origin of suffering, and also other than the mind base associated with future self-view.
The mind base that is a cause of the view of self and also a cause of the view of self refers to the mind base excluded above.
The mind base that is neither a cause of the view of self nor a cause of the view of self refers to the undefiled mind base.

original: æ³•è™•ï¼Œæˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› äº¦æœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–éæœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€‚
analyzed: æ³•è™•ï¼Œæˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› äº¦æœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–éæœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€‚
translated: The dharma base is either a cause of the view of self but not a cause of the view of self, or it is a cause of the view of self and also a cause of the view of self, or it is neither a cause of the view of self nor a cause of the view of self.

The dharma-element that is a cause of the view of the self but is not a cause of the view of the self is the dharma-element that is excluded from the past and present contaminants abandoned by the path of vision of suffering and the factors associated with them and coexisting with them, and also the dharma-element that is excluded from the past and present contaminants abandoned by the path of vision of the cause and the factors associated with them and coexisting with them, and also the dharma-element associated with the view of the self in the future, and also the arising, old age, duration, and impermanence of the view of the self and the factors associated with it in the future. The remaining defiled dharma-element.
The dharma-element that is a cause of the view of the self and is also a cause of the view of the self is the dharma-element that was excluded above.
The dharma-element that is not a cause of the view of the self and is not a cause of the view of the self is the undefiled dharma-element.

How many are karma and how many are not karma? How many are karmic results and how many are not karmic results? All should be discriminated.ğŸ”½The eye-element is either a karmic result that is not karma, or it is neither a karmic result nor karma.
The eye-element that is a karmic result but is not karma refers to the eye-element that is born of karmic results. The remaining eye-element is neither a karmic result nor karma.
The same applies to the ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, body, touch, and mind bases.
The form base may be either an action that is not karmic retribution, or karmic retribution that is not an action, or neither an action nor karmic retribution.
That which is an action but not karmic retribution refers to bodily expression.
That which is karmic retribution but not an action refers to the form base that is produced by karmic retribution.

That which is neither an action nor karmic retribution refers to all form bases other than those that are actions or karmic retribution, and the sound base may be either an action that is not karmic retribution, or neither an action nor karmic retribution.
That which is an action but not karmic retribution refers to verbal expression, and all other sound bases are neither actions nor karmic retribution.

The dharma base has four possibilities.ğŸ”½Either an action that is not karmic retribution, referring to the dharma base that includes bodily and verbal actions, and volition that is not included in karmic retribution.
Either karmic retribution that is not an action, referring to the dharma base produced by karmic retribution that is not volition.
Or it is both action and the karmic maturation of action, namely volition that is karmically unripened.
Or it is neither action nor the karmic maturation of action, namely the other dharmas included in the sense field of mental objects, excluding action and the karmic maturation of action.
How many are action and not concomitant with action, etc.? Eight are neither action nor concomitant with action. One is concomitant with action but not action. Three should be distinguished.
Namely, the sense field of form, which may be action but not concomitant with action, or neither action nor concomitant with action.
That which is action but not concomitant with action refers to bodily expression. The other sense fields of form are neither action nor concomitant with action.
The sense field of sound, which may be action but not concomitant with action, or neither action nor concomitant with action.
That which is action but not concomitant with action refers to verbal expression. The other sense fields of sound are neither action nor concomitant with action.
The sense field of mental objects has four alternatives.

Or it is action but not concomitant with action, namely bodily and verbal action included in the sense field of mental objects, excluding bodily and verbal action that is concomitant with action, and volition.

Or it is that which is concomitant with action but not action itself, namely, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of conception, and the aggregate of formation not included in the aggregate of volition.
Or it is both action and that which is concomitant with action, namely, bodily and vocal action.
Or it is neither action nor that which is concomitant with action, namely, the element of factors excluding action and that which is concomitant with action, and the rest of the elements.
As for how many are derivative form but not visible form, etc., there are three sentences.
Or it is derivative form but not visible form, namely, eight elements and part of two elements.
Or it is both derivative form and visible form, namely, one element.
Or it is neither derivative form nor visible form, namely, one element and part of two elements.
As for how many are derivative form but not resistant form, etc., there are four sentences.ğŸ”½Or it is derivative form but not resistant form, namely, part of one element.
Or it is resistant form but not derivative form, namely, part of one element.
Or, derivative form is also resistant form, namely the nine sense bases and a part of one sense base.
Or, it is neither derivative form nor resistant form, namely one sense base and a part of one sense base.
As for how many are difficult to see and therefore profound, etc., all are difficult to see and therefore profound, and profound and therefore difficult to see.
As for how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc., all should be discriminated.
That is to say, the eye sense base may be a cause of the wholesome but not wholesome, or neither a cause of the wholesome nor wholesome.
A cause of the wholesome but not wholesome refers to the eye sense base born of wholesome karmic maturation. The remaining eye sense bases are neither a cause of the wholesome nor wholesome.
The ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, body, and tangible object sense bases are also the same.
The form sense base may be a cause of the wholesome but not wholesome, or wholesome and also a cause of the wholesome, or neither a cause of the wholesome nor wholesome.
A cause of the wholesome but not wholesome refers to the form sense base born of wholesome karmic maturation.
Wholesome and also a cause of the wholesome refers to wholesome form sense bases.

The form base that is neither wholesome nor unwholesome as its cause refers to the form base that is neither wholesome nor unwholesome as its cause, except for the form base that is the result of wholesome karma.
The mind base is also like this.
The sound base may be wholesome and also have wholesome as its cause, or it may be neither wholesome nor have wholesome as its cause.
That which is wholesome and also has wholesome as its cause refers to the wholesome sound base. The remaining sound bases are neither wholesome nor have wholesome as their cause.
The dharma base has four cases.
That which is wholesome but does not have wholesome as its cause refers to cessation resulting from discrimination.
That which has wholesome as its cause but is not wholesome refers to the dharma base that is the result of wholesome karma.
That which is wholesome and also has wholesome as its cause refers to the wholesome conditioned dharma base.
That which is neither wholesome nor has wholesome as its cause refers to the remaining unwholesome and indeterminate dharma bases, except for the dharma base that is the result of wholesome karma.
How many are unwholesome but not due to unwholesome causes, etc.? All should be discriminated.
The eye base may be due to unwholesome causes but not unwholesome, or it may be neither due to unwholesome causes nor unwholesome.

The eye base that is not unwholesome but has unwholesome causes refers to the eye base that is the result of unwholesome karmic maturation, and the other eye bases that are neither unwholesome nor have unwholesome causes.
The ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, body, and tactile bases are also like this.
The form base may be a cause of unwholesomeness but is not unwholesome, or it may be both unwholesome and a cause of unwholesomeness, or it may be neither unwholesome nor a cause of unwholesomeness.
A cause of unwholesomeness but not unwholesome refers to the form base that is the result of unwholesome karmic maturation.
Both unwholesome and a cause of unwholesomeness refers to the unwholesome form base.
Neither unwholesome nor a cause of unwholesomeness refers to the form base that is the result of unwholesome karmic maturation, and the other form bases that are neither wholesome nor unwholesome.
The sound base may be unwholesome and also a cause of unwholesomeness, or it may be neither unwholesome nor a cause of unwholesomeness.
Unwholesome and also a cause of unwholesomeness refers to the unwholesome sound base. The other sound bases are neither unwholesome nor causes of unwholesomeness.

The mental faculty may be a cause of what is unwholesome but not unwholesome itself, or it may be both unwholesome and a cause of what is unwholesome, or it may be neither unwholesome nor a cause of what is unwholesome.

A cause of what is unwholesome but not unwholesome itself refers to the mental faculty that is the karmic ripening of what is unwholesome, and to the mental faculty associated with the views of the existence of a self and the views of grasping extremes in the desire realm.
Both unwholesome and a cause of what is unwholesome refers to the unwholesome mental faculty.

Neither unwholesome nor a cause of what is unwholesome refers to the wholesome and indeterminate mental faculties, excluding the mental faculty that is the karmic ripening of what is unwholesome, and excluding the mental faculty associated with the views of the existence of a self and the views of grasping extremes in the desire realm.

The factor element may be a cause of what is unwholesome but not unwholesome itself, or it may be both unwholesome and a cause of what is unwholesome, or it may be neither unwholesome nor a cause of what is unwholesome.

That which is not good but not caused by the bad is the dharma element born of retribution of the bad, and the view of individuality and the view of grasping extremes in the realm of desire, and the dharma element associated with them, and the formations dissociated from mind produced by them.
That which is bad and also caused by the bad is the dharma element produced by the bad.

That which is neither bad nor caused by the bad is the dharma element born of retribution of the bad, and the view of individuality and the view of grasping extremes in the realm of desire, and the dharma element associated with them, and the formations dissociated from mind produced by them, and the other indeterminate and good dharma elements, with the exception of the dharma element born of retribution of the bad.
As for how many are indeterminate but not caused by the indeterminate, etc., eight are indeterminate and also caused by the indeterminate, four should be distinguished.

That is to say, the form element is either caused by the indeterminate but not indeterminate, or indeterminate and also caused by the indeterminate, or neither caused by the indeterminate nor indeterminate.
That which is caused by the indeterminate but not indeterminate is the bad form element.
The indeterminate [form] is also the cause of the indeterminate [form]. This refers to the indeterminate form base.
That which is neither indeterminate nor the cause of the indeterminate [form] refers to the wholesome form base.
The sound base and the mind base are also like this.
The dharma base has four alternatives.
Either indeterminate and not the cause of the indeterminate [dharmas], referring to space and non-analytical cessation.
Either the cause of the indeterminate [dharmas] but not indeterminate [itself], referring to the unwholesome dharma base.
Either indeterminate and also the cause of the indeterminate [dharmas], referring to the conditioned indeterminate dharma base.
Either not indeterminate and not the cause of the indeterminate [dharmas], referring to the wholesome dharma base.

original: å¹¾å› ç·£éæœ‰å› ç­‰è€…ï¼Œåä¸€æ˜¯å› ç·£äº¦æœ‰å› ï¼Œä¸€æ‡‰åˆ†åˆ¥ï¼Œè¬‚æ³•è™•ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰ç‚ºæ˜¯å› ç·£äº¦æœ‰å› ï¼Œè‹¥ç„¡ç‚ºéå› ç·£éæœ‰å› ã€‚
analyzed: å¹¾å› ç·£éæœ‰å› ç­‰è€…ï¼Œåä¸€æ˜¯å› ç·£äº¦æœ‰å› ï¼Œä¸€æ‡‰åˆ†åˆ¥ï¼Œè¬‚æ³•è™•ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰ç‚ºæ˜¯å› ç·£äº¦æœ‰å› ï¼Œè‹¥ç„¡ç‚ºéå› ç·£éæœ‰å› ã€‚
translated: As for how many are conditions and yet not causes, eleven are conditions and also have causes. One should be distinguished, namely the dharma base. If conditioned, it is a condition and also has causes. If unconditioned, it is neither a condition nor has causes.

As for how many are immediately preceding conditions but not the same as the immediately preceding condition, ten are not the immediately preceding condition and also not the same as the immediately preceding condition. Two should be distinguished.

It is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, or it is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is also a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, or it is neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent.

It is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to the present mental faculty that is about to arise in the future, and the mental faculty of an arhat at the time of final nirvÄá¹‡a in the past and present.

It is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is also a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to all past and present mental faculties, except for the mental faculty of an arhat at the time of final nirvÄá¹‡a in the past and present.

It is neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to all future mental faculties, except for the present mental faculty that is about to arise in the future.

The dharma element is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, or it is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent that is also a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, or it is neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent.

Those that are immediately preceding conditions but not similar and immediately preceding conditions are future presently arising mental factors, and past and present mental factors at the time of the final nirvÄá¹‡a of arhats, as well as the already arisen and presently occurring states of non-perception and cessation.
Those that are both immediately preceding and similar and immediately preceding conditions are all past and present mental factors, except for those at the time of the final nirvÄá¹‡a of arhats.

Those that are neither immediately preceding nor similar and immediately preceding conditions are all future mental factors except for those presently arising, all formations not associated with the mind except for those immediately preceding, as well as bodily and verbal actions, space, and the two cessations.

As for how many are objects of cognition but not possessors of objects of cognition, and so on, ten are objects of cognition but not possessors of objects of cognition, one is both an object of cognition and a possessor of objects of cognition, and one should be distinguished.
That is to say, the dharma realm, if it is a mental factor, is both an object-condition and has an object. If it is not a mental factor, it is an object-condition but does not have an object.

As for how many are dominant conditions but do not have dominance, eleven are dominant conditions and also have dominance. One should be distinguished, namely the dharma realm. If it is conditioned, it is a dominant condition and also has dominance. If it is unconditioned, it is a dominant condition but does not have dominance.
As for how many are floods but not in conformity with the floods, ten are in conformity with the floods but not floods, and two should be distinguished.
That is to say, the mind realm, if it is contaminated, is in conformity with the floods but not a flood. If it is uncontaminated, it is neither a flood nor in conformity with the floods.
The dharma realm, either in conformity with the floods but not a flood, or a flood and also in conformity with the floods, or neither a flood nor in conformity with the floods.
In conformity with the floods but not a flood refers to the contaminated dharma realm not included in the floods.
A flood and also in conformity with the floods refers to the four floods.
Those that are neither floods nor that which is favorable to the floods refer to the element of the uncontaminated dharmas.
The five aggregates are the form aggregate, and so on up to the consciousness aggregate.
As for these five aggregates, how many have form, and so on? One has form, and four are formless.
How many are visible, and so on? Four are invisible, and one should be distinguished, namely, the form aggregate. It is either visible or invisible.
What is visible?
It is one sense base.
What is invisible?
It is nine sense bases and a part of one sense base.
How many are resistant, and so on? Four are non-resistant, and one should be distinguished, namely, the form aggregate. It is either resistant or non-resistant.
What is resistant?
It is ten sense bases.
What is non-resistant?
It is one sense base and a part of another.
How many are contaminated, and so on? All should be distinguished.
Namely, the form aggregate is either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What is contaminated?
It is ten sense bases and a part of one sense base.
What is uncontaminated?
It refers to a small part of one place.
The aggregate of feeling may be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What is contaminated?
It refers to the aggregate of feeling associated with contaminated attention.
What is uncontaminated?
It refers to the aggregate of feeling associated with uncontaminated attention.
The same applies to the aggregates of perception and consciousness.
The aggregate of volitional formations may be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What is contaminated?
It refers to the aggregate of volitional formations associated with contaminated mind and those not associated with mind.
What is uncontaminated?
It refers to the aggregate of volitional formations associated with uncontaminated mind and those not associated with mind.
As for how many are conditioned, all are conditioned.
As for how many have karmic retribution, all should be analyzed.
The aggregate of form may have karmic retribution or be without karmic retribution.
What has karmic retribution?
It refers to the aggregate of form that is unwholesome and wholesome and contaminated.
What is without karmic retribution?
It refers to the aggregate of form that is indeterminate and uncontaminated.
The same applies to the remaining four aggregates.
As for how many are conditionally originated, etc.: all are conditionally originated, originated from causes, and included in the world.
As for how many are categorized as form, etc.: one is categorized as form, four are categorized as name.
As for how many are categorized as internal sense bases, etc.: one is categorized as an internal sense base, three are categorized as external sense bases, one should be discriminated.
This means that the aggregate of form is either categorized as an internal sense base or categorized as an external sense base.
How is it categorized as an internal sense base?
It means the five internal sense bases.
How is it categorized as an external sense base?
It means the five external sense bases and a small part of one external sense base.
As for how many are known by the knowledge of elimination, etc.: all are known by the knowledge of elimination.

As for how many are known by the thorough knowledge of elimination, etc.: all should be discriminated. This means that if the aggregates are contaminated, they are known by the thorough knowledge of elimination; if they are uncontaminated, they are not known by the thorough knowledge of elimination.

As for how many are to be eliminated and so on, all should be distinguished. That is, the aggregates, if contaminated, are to be eliminated; if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.ğŸ”½As for how many are to be cultivated and so on, all should be distinguished. That is, the aggregates, if wholesome, are to be cultivated; if not wholesome, they are not to be cultivated.
As for how many are defiled and so on, all should be distinguished. That is, the aggregates, if covered, are defiled; if uncovered, they are not defiled.
As for how many are results but not causes of results and so on, all are results and also have results.
As for how many are appropriated and so on, four are not appropriated, and one should be distinguished. That is, the form aggregate may be either appropriated or not appropriated.
What is appropriated?
It refers to the form aggregate included in one's own continuum.
What is not appropriated?
It refers to the form aggregate not included in one's own continuum.

How many are derived from the four great elements? Four are not derived from the four great elements. One should be distinguished, namely the form aggregate. It may be derived from the four great elements or not derived from the four great elements.
How is it derived from the four great elements?
It refers to nine sense bases and part of two sense bases.
How is it not derived from the four great elements?
It refers to part of one sense base.
How many have superior? All have superior.
How many are existence? All should be distinguished. The aggregates, if contaminated, are existence. If uncontaminated, they are not existence.
How many are associated with causes? One is not associated with causes. Three are associated with causes. One should be distinguished.
Namely, the formation aggregate. If it is a mental factor, it is associated with causes. If it is not a mental factor, it is not associated with causes.
As for the five aggregates and the six wholesome bases, there are four possibilities.
Either wholesome bases but not aggregates, namely cessation through deliberation.
Or, the aggregates are not wholesome bases, namely the five aggregates that are unwholesome or indeterminate.
Or, the wholesome bases are also the aggregates, namely the five wholesome aggregates.
Or, neither the wholesome bases nor the aggregates, namely space and non-analytical cessation.

As for the relationship between the five unwholesome bases and the five aggregates, the five unwholesome bases subsume part of the five aggregates, and part of the five aggregates also subsumes the five unwholesome bases.
As for the relationship between the seven indeterminate bases and the five aggregates, there are four possibilities.
Or, the indeterminate bases are not the aggregates, namely space and non-analytical cessation.
Or, the aggregates are not the indeterminate bases, namely the wholesome and unwholesome five aggregates.
Or, the indeterminate bases are also the aggregates, namely the indeterminate five aggregates.
Or, neither the indeterminate bases nor the aggregates, namely analytical cessation.

As for the relationship between the three bases of contaminants and the five aggregates, the three bases of contaminants subsume part of one aggregate, and part of one aggregate also subsumes the three bases of contaminants.

As for the correspondence with the five contaminated sense bases, the five contaminated sense bases include part of the five aggregates, and part of the five aggregates also includes the five contaminated sense bases.
As for the correspondence with the eight uncontaminated sense bases, four sentences should be made.
Either uncontaminated sense bases that are not aggregates, namely space and the two cessations.
Either aggregates that are not uncontaminated sense bases, namely the contaminated five aggregates.
Either uncontaminated sense bases that are also aggregates, namely the uncontaminated five aggregates.
Either not uncontaminated sense bases and not aggregates, such a case cannot be found.
As for how many are past, etc., all are either past, future, or present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., all should be discriminated. That is to say, the aggregates are either wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to the wholesome five aggregates.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to the unwholesome five aggregates.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to the indeterminate five aggregates.
How many are bound to the desire realm, etc.? All should be discriminated.
That is, the aggregates are either bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, bound to the formless realm, or unbound.
How are they bound to the desire realm?
They are the five aggregates of the desire realm.
How are they bound to the form realm?
They are the five aggregates of the form realm.
How are they bound to the formless realm?
They are the four aggregates of the formless realm.
How are they unbound?
They are the five uncontaminated aggregates.
How many are learner dharmas, etc.? All should be discriminated.
That is, the aggregates are either learner dharmas, non-learner dharmas, or neither learner nor non-learner dharmas.
What are learner dharmas?
They are the five aggregates of learners.
What are non-learner dharmas?
They are the five aggregates of non-learners.
What are neither learner nor non-learner dharmas?
They are the five contaminated aggregates.
How many of these five aggregates are to be eliminated by seeing, etc.? All should be discriminated.
It refers to the form aggregate, whether it is to be eliminated by cultivation with outflows, or it is pure and not to be eliminated.
The feeling aggregate may be eliminated by views, or it may be eliminated by cultivation, or it may not be eliminated.
How is it eliminated by views?
It refers to the feeling aggregate that is eliminated by the receptivity at the stage of the highest worldly factors of the followers of faith and the followers of the teachings.
What is this again?
It refers to the feeling aggregate associated with the eighty-eight latent afflictions to be eliminated by the path of seeing.
How is it eliminated by cultivation?
It refers to the feeling aggregate that is eliminated by cultivation by those who have entered the path of cultivation and have seen the traces of the path.
What is this again?
It refers to the feeling aggregate associated with the ten latent afflictions to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, and to the defiled and impure feeling aggregate.
How is it not to be eliminated?
It refers to the pure feeling aggregate.
The perception and consciousness aggregates are also like this.
The formation aggregate may be eliminated by views, or it may be eliminated by cultivation, or it may not be eliminated.
How is it eliminated by views?
It refers to the formation aggregate that is eliminated by the receptivity at the stage of the highest worldly factors of the followers of faith and the followers of the teachings.
What is this again?

That is to say, the aggregates of formations that are associated with the eighty-eight latent proclivities that are eliminated by the path of insight, as well as the formations that are not associated with thought that are produced in dependence on them.
What is eliminated by cultivation?
That is to say, the aggregate of formations that are eliminated by the path of cultivation by those who have entered the spiritual path and have not yet attained the stage of vision.
What is that?

That is to say, the ten latent proclivities that are eliminated by the path of cultivation, as well as the aggregates of formations that are associated with them, and the formations that are not associated with thought that are produced in dependence on them, and the defiled aggregate of formations.
What is not eliminated? That is to say, the pure aggregate of formations.
How many are not mind, etc.? One is not mind, nor is it associated with mind; two are associated with mind but are not mind; one is only mind; one must be distinguished.
That is to say, the aggregate of formations, if it has an object, is associated with mind and is a mental factor; if it has no object, it is neither mind nor associated with mind.

How many are concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling, etc.? One is concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling. One is associated with feeling but not concomitant with mind. One is both concomitant with mind and associated with feeling. Two should be distinguished.
Namely, the form aggregate. Either it is concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling, or it is neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling.

That which is concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling refers to bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with mind. The remaining form aggregate is neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling.
The formation aggregate has three phrases.
Either it is concomitant with mind but not associated with feeling, referring to formations that are neither form nor consciousness that are concomitant with mind.
Either it is both concomitant with mind and associated with feeling, referring to mental activities that are formations.
Either it is neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling, referring to formations that are neither form nor consciousness except for those that are concomitant with mind.
How many are concomitant with mind but not associated with conceptualization and feeling, etc.? Excluding the nature of conceptualization itself, it should be known as in the case of feeling.

The second is both concomitant with the mind and associated with mental activities. The third is only associated with mental activities and not concomitant with the mind. The fourth is neither concomitant with the mind nor associated with mental activities.
The aggregate of form is either concomitant with the mind but not associated with mental activities, or neither concomitant with the mind nor associated with mental activities.

That which is concomitant with the mind but not associated with mental activities refers to form that is bodily or vocal karma concomitant with the mind. The remaining aggregate of form is neither concomitant with the mind nor associated with mental activities.
The aggregate of mental activities is threefold.
That which is concomitant with the mind but not associated with mental activities refers to mental activities that are not associated with mind and are concomitant with the mind.
That which is both concomitant with the mind and associated with mental activities refers to mental activities that are included in the aggregate of mental activities and exclude their own natures.

That which is neither concomitant with the mind nor associated with mental activities refers to mental activities that are not associated with mind and are excluded from those concomitant with the mind.
How many are concomitant with applied thought but not with sustained thought, etc.? All should be discriminated.
The aggregate of form is either concomitant with applied thought but not with sustained thought, or neither concomitant with applied thought nor with sustained thought.

That which evolves with investigation but is not associated with applied thought refers to bodily and verbal actions that evolve with investigation. The other form aggregates do not evolve with investigation and are not associated with applied thought.
The feeling aggregate may be with investigation and applied thought, or without investigation but with applied thought, or without investigation or applied thought.
What is with investigation and applied thought?
It is the feeling aggregate associated with attention that is with investigation and applied thought.
What is without investigation but with applied thought?
It is the feeling aggregate associated with attention that is without investigation but with applied thought.
What is without investigation or applied thought?
It is the feeling aggregate associated with attention that is without investigation or applied thought.
The perception and consciousness aggregates are also like this.

The formation aggregate has four alternatives.ğŸ”½That which evolves with investigation but is not associated with applied thought refers to formations that do not accompany thought and evolve with investigation, and applied thought associated with investigation.ğŸ”½That which is associated with applied thought but does not evolve with investigation refers to investigation and formations that do not accompany thought but are associated with applied thought.
That which evolves with investigation and is also associated with applied thought refers to formations that accompany thought and are associated with investigation and applied thought.

Or it is neither concomitant with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, referring to those formations dissociated from thought other than those concomitant with applied thought, and those formations dissociated from thought that are not associated with sustained thought, and the formations of the aggregate of mental activities that are neither applied thought nor sustained thought.
How many are views and not objects of views, etc.? All should be discriminated.
That is to say, the aggregate of form has three sentences.
Or it is an object of views but not a view, referring to nine sense bases and part of one sense base.
Or it is a view and also an object of views, referring to one sense base.
Or it is neither a view nor an object of views, referring to part of one sense base.
The aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness, if contaminated, are objects of views but not views; if uncontaminated, they are neither views nor objects of views.
The aggregate of formations has four sentences.
Or it is a view but not an object of views, referring to uncontaminated discernment not included in the knowledge of elimination and non-production.
Or it is an object of views but not a view, referring to the aggregate of formations that are contaminated and not included in views.
Or it is both a view and an object of views, referring to the five defiled views and mundane right views.
Or neither seen nor not seen, referring to the uncontaminated aggregates of activity not included in seeing.
Or neither seen nor seen-base, referring to the uncontaminated aggregate of volitional formations not included in the seen.
